questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes nitroimidazoles? Metronidazole inhibits bacterial DNA synthesis by interacting directly with DNA. Metronidazole is a prodrug converted to its active form by the bacterial nitroreductase enzyme. Secnidazole is one of the shortest-acting nitroimidazoles. Metronidazole inhibits the PFOR enzyme, which damages DNA in protozoa. Resistance occurs through the activation of nitric oxide free radicals.
questions.explanation:
Nitroimidazoles

MOA
  • Prodrug is converted to active form through nitro group reduction inside the bacteria(Statement 2) → formation of nitric oxide free radicals → causes DNA damage→ inhibits replication(Statement 1)
  • Inhibits PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) in protozoa → causing DNA damage(Statement 4)

Drugs
  • Metronidazole
  • Ornidazole
  • Tinidazole
  • Satranidazole
  • Secnidazole: longest acting drug
  • Other: Benznidazole, Nifurtimox, Nitazoxanide

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of abdominal pain and loose stools for the past two weeks but no h/o fever. He has recently returned from a vacation to Nepal. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Stool testing shows mucoid stool with elevated white cell counts. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.explanation:
Metronidazole

Coverage

Broad spectrum anaerobes (Bacteroides, Clostridium, Fusobacterium, Peptococcus, etc.)

Uses
  1. Giardiasis (in HIV-positive patients)
  2. Entamoeba histolytica → Amebic dysentery & amebic liver abscess
  3. Trichomonas vaginalis
  4. Bacterial Vaginosis
  5. Dracunculus (guinea worm)
  6. Gardenella / bacterial vaginosis
  7. Empiric intra-abdomina and soft tissue anaerobic infections
  8. H. pylori gastritis (combined with proton pump inhibitor)
  9. Prophylaxis for colorectal surgery
  10. Fulminant C.difficile infection (IV metronidazole + oral vancomycin)
  11. Mild to moderate Crohn's disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements about second-generation fluoroquinolones is false?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a broader spectrum of activity compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.

options.label: B
options.text: They inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a shorter half-life compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.

options.label: D
options.text: They can cause QT prolongation as a side effect.

questions.correct_answer: C. They have a shorter half-life compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.
questions.explanation:
First Generation

Second Generation

Drugs

 

Mnemonic: New COP has Small Lite Machine Gun
  • Norfloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Ofloxacin
  • Pefloxacin
  • Sparfloxacin
  • Levofloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Gemifloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Moderate half-life
  • Good oral absorption
  • Longer half-life(Option C is the false statement)
  • Better tissue penetration

Mechanism of Action

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV(Option B)

Spectrum

Effective against Gram-negative bacteria

Broader spectrum, including Gram (+ve), Gram (-ve) and Atypical pathogens.(Option A)

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Respiratory infections (e.g.Pneumonia)
  • Skin infections
  • Complicated UTIs

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Dizziness
  • QT prolongation(Option D)
  • Tendonitis
  • CNS effects
  • Phototoxicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Same as first generation
  • Patients with cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: Match the following antibiotics with their appropriate mechanism of action. Drugs Mechanism of action 1 Linezolid A. Blocks 50s ribosomal subunit; interferes with translocation 2 Tetracycline B. Block 23s subunit on 50s ribosome, interferes with formylmethionine-tRNA 70S complex formation 3 Erythromycin C. Blocks 30s ribosomal subunit; causes misreading of mRNA 4 Streptomycin D. Blocks 30S mRNA-ribosome; inhibits attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site.
questions.explanation:
Drugs

Ribosomal subunit blocked

Effect

Linezolid

Block 23s subunit on 50s ribosome.

Interferes with formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex formation, thus preventing protein synthesis.

Tetracycline /tigecycline

Doxycycline

Demeclocycline

Minocycline

Blocks 30S mRNA - ribosome.

Inhibits attachment of aminoacyl-t-RNA to the acceptor (A) site.

Aminoglycosides

  • Streptomycin
  • Amikacin
  • Misreading of mRNA
  • Inhibit polysome formation (Attachment of ribosomes on mRNA)
  • Inhibits initiation of protein synthesis

Chloramphenicol

Blocks 50s ribosomal subunit.

Inhibits transfer of the elongating peptide chain

to the newly attached aminoacyl-tRNA.

Macrolides

  • Erythromycin
  • Azithromycin

Interferes with translocation.

questions.text: A drug sensitivity test of a patient's sputum sample shows the presence of vancomycin-resistant MRSA. A narrow-spectrum protein synthesis inhibitor antibiotic that inhibits the formation of formylmethionine-tRNA 70S initiation complex was started for the patient. Which drug was most likely used?
questions.explanation:
Spectrum

Antibiotics

Uses

Broad spectrum

Effective against a wide range of bacteria, including both Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms.

Chloramphenicol (Option C)



 
  • Pyogenic meningitis (Second line)
  • Endophthalmitis
  • Anaerobic infections

Tetracycline
  • Chlamydia
  • Bacillus anthrax
  • Psittacosis

Clindamycin

(Option D)
  • Ance
  • Anaerobic infections
  • Drug-resistant Malaria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Intermediate spectrum

Typically, they cover Gram-positive or Gram-negative bacteria, but not both extensively.

Macrolides

  • Azithromycin (Option A)
  • Erythromycin
  • Atypical pneumonia
  • Whooping cough
  • Chlamydia

Narrow spectrum

Effective against a limited range of bacteria.

Aminoglycoside

  • Streptomycin
  • Amikacin
  • Tuberculosis
  • Tularemia
  • Neonatal sepsis

Linezolid (Option B)
  • Vancomycin-resistant MRSA.
  • VRE.

Streptogramin
  • MRSA
  • Penicillin-resistant streptococcus pneumonia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a history of multiple sexual partners comes to the clinic with an inguinal swelling. Physical examination findings are given below. What would be the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Features

Tetracycline

Oxytetracycline

Demeclocycline

Doxycycline

Minocycline

Potency

Low

Intermediate

High

Plasma protein binding

Low

High

high

Half-life

6 - 12 hours

10 -16 hours

18- 24 hours

Alteration of gut flora

Altered

Moderate alteration

Least alteration

Phototoxicity

Low

Highest

High

Other toxicity

Tooth discoloration is less marked

Diabetes insipidus
  • Doxycycline has low nephrotoxicity.
  • Minocycline has 0totoxicity.

Uses of Tetracyclines
  • Chlamydial Infections: Urethritis, Endocervicitis, Lymphogranuloma venereum, granuloma inguinale.
  • Atypical Pneumonia: Mycoplasma pneumonia, Psittacosis.
  • Rickettsial Infections.
  • Pleurodesis: Doxycycline for pneumothorax.
  • H. pylori Infection: Part of quadruple therapy.
  • Anthrax, Plague, Borrelia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic man presents with a severe UTI, showing high fever, chills, and dysuria. Urine culture reveals E. coli resistant to aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones. What mechanism likely contributes to E. coli's resistance to aminoglycosides?

options.label: A
options.text: Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes

options.label: B
options.text: Alteration of the bacterial ribosomal binding site

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased uptake of the drug into bacterial cells

options.label: D
options.text: Formation of biofilms on mucosal surfaces

questions.correct_answer: A. Inactivation of the drug by bacterial enzymes
questions.explanation:
Aminoglycosides

Mechanism of action

Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, causing misreading of mRNA.

Drugs

Streptomycin, Gentamicin, Tobramycin, Amikacin, Neomycin, Netilmicin

Spectrum

Primarily Gram-negative aerobic bacteria; limited Gram-positive coverage. Includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae.

Uses
  • Serious Gram-negative infections (e.g., sepsis, pneumonia)
  • Tuberculosis (Streptomycin)
  • Endocarditis (Gentamicin in combination therapy)

Resistance mechanism
  • Enzymatic inactivation by acetyltransferases, phosphotransferases, and nucleotidyltransferases.
  • Alteration of the 30S ribosomal binding site.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with COPD develops severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and fever two weeks after being treated with ceftriaxone and clindamycin. Stool testing confirms Clostridioides difficile infection. An endoscopic image shows pseudomembranous colitis. Which antibiotic is the most appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.explanation:
Drugs which increase the risk of Pseudomembranous colitis

Drugs useful in Pseudomembranous colitis
  • Clindamycin (highest risk)
  • Cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone)
  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin)
  • Penicillins (e.g., ampicillin, amoxicillin)
  • Metronidazole (mild and pediatric cases)
  • Vancomycin
  • Fidaxomicin
  • Rifaximin
  • Bezlotoxumab (new FDA approved drug)

questions.text: All of the following drugs correctly match their mechanism of action. 1. Cycloserine a. Inhibits enzyme bactoprenol dephosphorylase 2. Fosfomycin b. Inhibits enzyme transpeptidase 3. Monobactam c. Inhibits enzyme enol pyruvate transferase 4. Bacitracin d. Inhibits enzyme alanine racemase and ligase
questions.explanation:
Cell wall synthesis inhibitors

MOA

Drugs

Uses

Side effects

Inhibits transpeptidase (penicillin-binding protein) and prevents cross-linking

Beta-lactam drugs

1. Penicillin

2. Cephalosporin

3. Carbapenems

4. Monobactam (Aztreonam)
  • MSSA infections
  • Perioperative prophylaxis
  • Syphilis
  • Meningitis
  • Community-acquired pneumonia
  • GI and GU infection
  • Aztreonam in penicillin allergy.
  • Ertapenam in ESBL, P. aeruginosa, and Acinetobacter

1. Hypersensitivity

2. Cross hypersensitivity (except monobactams)

Inhibits enol pyruvate transferase and block GAG synthesis

Fosfomycin
  • Enterococcal UTI (Foley's catheter)
  • Transurethral procedures
  • Safe in pregnancy

1. Hematuria

2. Urinary discomfort

3. Neuropsychiatric: Psychosis, seizures

D-alanine analogue inhibits alanine racemase and ligase

(Bacteriostatic)

Cycloserine
  • Multidrug resistant TB

1. Neurotoxicity

2. Psychosis

3. Depression (Suicide risk)

Inhibits bactoprenol dephosphorylase enzyme

Bacitracin
  • Topical cream in gram-positive cocci (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus) skin infection
  • Oral: Enterococcal infection

1. Nephrotoxic (IV)

2. Bone marrow suppression

Inhibition of transglucosidase enzyme

Vancomycin
  • Pseudomembranous colitis(oral)
  • MRSA
  • E. faecalis

1. Nephrotoxicity

2. Ototoxicity

3. Red man syndrome

questions.text: Penicillin is helpful for the treatment of all of the following conditions except?
questions.explanation:
Penicillins

Classification
  • Natural Penicillins
    • Penicillin G/Benzylpenicillin/Crystalline penicillin
      • First penicillin
      • Parenteral route only
      • Allergic potential
      • Narrow spectrum
      • Resistance exhibited by beta-lactamase enzyme-producing organisms
      •  
    • Penicillin V: Enteral route
  • Penicillinase resistant penicillin
    • Methicillin, cloxacillin, nafcillin, oxacillin, and dicloxacillin
  • Aminopenicillins: Ampicillin, amoxicillin.
  • Anti-pseudomonal penicillins: Piperacillin, ticarcillin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Poor CNS penetration (except Penicillin G and nafcillin)
  • Poor eye penetration
  • Poor prostate penetration

Uses (SMART Player GAYLE)
  • S: Syphilis: DOC for neurosyphilis (Option B ruled out)
  • M: Meningococcal meningitis
  • A: Actinomycosis
  • R: Rat bite fever: Streptobacillus, Spirillosis
  • T: Tetanus
  • Player: Pasteurella multocida
  • G: Gas gangrene (Myonecrosis): Clostridium perfringens
  • A: Anthrax
  • Y: Yaws
  • L: Leptospirosis (Option D ruled out)
  • E: Every species: Streptococcus, Staphylococcus if sensitive (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the hospital with headaches, difficulty coordinating his movements, and memory loss over the past six months. On physical examination, his pupils are irregular and do not constrict to light but constrict during accommodation. He had a history of painless genital ulcer, which was resolved on its own a few years ago. What is the drug of choice used for this condition in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: A single dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G

options.label: B
options.text: Once weekly dose of 2.4 million IU penicillin G

options.label: C
options.text: Once weekly dose of 24 million IU penicillin G

options.label: D
options.text: Continues dose of 24 million IU penicillin G

questions.correct_answer: D. Continues dose of 24 million IU penicillin G
questions.explanation:
Stages of Syphilis

Treatment

Primary syphilis

Chancre (painless genital ulcer)

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU (Option A)

Secondary syphilis

Spread in blood: Rash involving palms and soles, uveitis

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Early latent syphilis

Dormant for < 1 year

Single IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU

Late latent syphilis

Dormant for > 1 year

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option B)

Tertiary syphilis

Activation after one year and damages the organs (gummas)

Weekly IM Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million IU for three weeks (Option C)

Damage to heart: Cardiovascular syphilis (aortic aneurysm, arteritis)

Damage to the brain: Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis, ataxia, dementia, Argyl Robertson pupils)

Continues IV Aqueous Penicillin G 18-24 IU for 10-14 days. (Option D)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male recently began treatment for painless lesions in his palms and soles and presented to the emergency department with fever, chills, and myalgias. These symptoms developed a few hours after receiving his first dose of benzathine penicillin G. On examination, he appears flushed (image) with tachycardia and hypotension. Based on the findings, match the most likely diagnosis and management of this condition. 1. Anaphylactic reaction A. Continue medication and start antipyretics 2. Serum Sickness B. Administer epinephrine 3. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction C. Discontinue and switch to alternate medication 4. Steven-Johnson syndrome D. Discontinue medication and admit to ICU

A patient who was admitted with suspected osteomyelitis is found to be caused by Staphylococcus aureus that shows resistance to methicillin. Which of the following is least likely to be the drug of choice for this patient?

A patient who initially presented with symptoms of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is found to be methicillin-resistant. The report also said vancomycin would also be ineffective in this organism. Which of the following cephalosporins can most likely be used effectively in this patient?
questions.explanation:
First generation
  • ENT, upper respiratory & cutaneous infections
  • Cephazolin is the DOC for surgical site infection prophylaxis 

Second generation
  • Mixed aerobic-anaerobic infections (Only cephalosporin class effective against anaerobes)
 

Third generation
  • Ceftriaxone/Cefotaxime: empirical therapy for meningitis
  • Ceftazidime: Pseudomonas meningitis
  • STI : Gonorrhea, chancroid, syphilis
  • Enteric fever
  • Patients with neutropenia

Fourth generation
  • Nosocomial infections (intensive care borne)
 

Fifth generation
  • Penicillin resistant community acquired and hospital acquired pneumonia by S.pneumoniae
  • Penicillinase producing S.aureus infections
  • MRSA
